text:
So I was in this meeting recently when someone
comments on me being ambitious by saying,
“It’s because you’re so Type A”
And I’m like okay...
Wait...
What?

Because in my years of study and research
I hadn’t  come across “Type A” personality
in psychology.

But lots of websites define Type A individuals
as competitive, impatient, ambitious,

high-achieving workaholics and people use
it in conversation all the time.
[Amy Santiago] I wouldn't say I'm controlling, I would say I'm Type A.
So from this one throwaway comment, I became

fixated on where Type A personality came from, which
maybe validates that person’s comment
that I have those personality traits.
And when I asked, is type A real?

What I discovered was a story of fraud, corruption,
and murder.
[Chris Moltisanti] There he goes, Mr. Type A personality.

Okay, that sell was very over the top but
it’s actually a really interesting story.
This episode is sponsored by Brilliant

To get back to the basics, Type A personalities
are described as outgoing, ambitious workaholics.

And then there’s Type B personalities, they’re
more relaxed and patient with a go-with-the-flow
attitude.

But Type A and Type B personalities weren’t
developed by psychologists.

Instead, they came from an unlikely partnership
between two cardiologists and the tobacco industry,

attempting to link personality traits
to the risk of heart disease.

In the 1950s, cigarettes were getting a pretty
bad rap for being linked to various health concerns.

And in 1952, after Reader’s Digest published
an article linking cigarettes to cancer, tobacco

companies didn’t want people thinking that
their product could kill them, so they ramped

up their marketing campaigns and funded research
to blur the lines between cigarettes and disease.

So in 1959, two cardiologists first published
a study describing Type A and Type B personality
and linking Type A to heart disease.

Some of the specific traits that the doctors
included were honestly quite strange.

So people were characterised as type A if
they had “a general air of impatience”

or if they engaged in “excessive gesturing”
and who knows the threshold when gesturing

becomes excessive, because I would probably
cross it.

Anyway, tobacco companies claimed that it
wasn’t cigarettes that led to heart disease.

They said that Type A people were more likely
to smoke cigarettes, so it was their

aggressive, impulsive behavior that led to
their risk of heart disease.

If there was any habit to be kicked, it
was changing their personalities, not their cigarettes.
Of course, hindsight is beautiful, but this is a pretty epic example of gaslighting if I’ve ever seen one.
Now the majority of follow-up studies did not

find a significant link between Type A
personality and heart disease, but

the tobacco industry continued to fund this
research for 40 years until the late 90s.

That’s a really long time to be doing kind
of bogus research.

It wasn’t until a 1998 court decision that
forced the tobacco industry to turn over nearly

40,000 documents that we all learned the extent
of their manipulation of health research.

I do want to take a moment here to say that
– while this big corporate behaviour was

super dodgy – research today has come a
long way in disclosing conflicts of interest,

where research is getting funding from, and
generally is pretty heavily scrutinised so

you’re not going to get gaslit about your
health...we hope.

Most importantly, cardiologists now would
not do what those two cardiologists did in 1959.
That’s right. Medicine has changed hugely.
Medical research is far from perfect, but it’s come a long way since the 1950s
and has a strict code of ethics it has to adhere to with all sources of funding having to be made public.
I’d like to think cardiologists, like me, would no longer willfully mislead and misrepresent data.
We certainly wouldn’t take money from the tobacco industry
because we get plenty from 5G manufacturers in the coronavirus coverup.
Oh God, I've said too much.
Now if being Type A
is a strong part of your identity…

I’m sorry because recent studies suggest
that Type A and Type B personality types don’t
actually exist.

Sure, we all have personality traits that
could fit into Type A or Type B, but now we

think that personality traits exist on a spectrum,
they’re not binary.
So you exist somewhere in between the two extremes.

For example, most of you would not be 100%
introverted or 100% extraverted, you would
exist somewhere on that continuum.

Which is why most personality research now
uses the Big Five, or the OCEAN model, where

you’re mapped across how open you are to
new experiences, how conscientious, extraverted
and agreeable you are, and neuroticism.

And while this link between Type A personality
and heart disease started out as smoke and

mirrors, there is a takeaway from this research:
personality can affect your health.

But like most psychology research, the picture
is a little complicated.

For example, one trait – neuroticism – seems
to lead to more illnesses.

It’s associated with a higher risk of depression,
anxiety, substance use disorder, and gastrointestinal conditions.
That sounds pretty bad, right?

But on the other hand being a little neurotic
has been associated with people living longer,

perhaps because when you are a little neurotic,
those feelings cause you to seek out health
care more frequently.

Then there’s conscientiousness, which seems
to have the most consistent link to good health.

People who are more conscientious tend to
be more organised, have good impulse control,
and they also tend to live longer.

But, put your thinking cap on... is longevity
inherent to this personality trait OR does

the personality trait cause people more likely
to adopt certain behaviors which lead to them
living longer?

While in psychology there are few clear answers,
the second option is most likely.

Because overall, people who are conscientious
are less likely to drink excessively, to smoke,
to drive riskily, and to engage in all other kinds of risky behavior.

But you’re not doomed if you are not conscientious,
a lot of our behaviour is habits, which we
can change.

And we can also figure out how to best navigate
our lives by having a better understanding
of our personality traits.

One exercise is to identify your personal
triggers, your energisers, and your managers.
I promise this is practical.

If you are more neurotic, identify what makes
you anxious or nervous,
and how you can best prepare for or manage those situations.

If you’re more introverted in that you're
drained by crowds and energised by solitude,

set goals and
deadlines so you can get things done before
you’re in a crowded space.

If you’re more laid back, use a daily to-do
list or if you’re more detail-orientated,
make sure you plan some downtime for yourself.

Of course it’s fun to type yourself and
say “I’m a Slytherin” or “I’m a Stark”

but one of the benefits of really understanding
your personality is to be able to adjust your behavior
to better suit your well-being.

And the one benefit of that dodgy Type A personality research
is it actually prompted us to look at the link between
personality and health.

And in the event that your personality
is linked to poorer health, it doesn’t

mean that’s predetermined and you can't
create good habits, because you can.

Instead of resigning yourself to the fact
that you’re just Type B or you’re 99%

lazy or – this is my personal one – you’re
too anxious to relax, we all have the power to build

healthy behaviors that ultimately
lead to better well-being.
And the other thing that the two cardiologists did not know
that 2020 would officially become the year of statistics.
If you would like to join me in brushing up on your statistics
Brilliant is the place to do it.
There a science and maths enrichment learning platform that has lots of fun stuff
from daily challenges to short courses.
I like Brilliant because they make learning easy for all different levels.
I have needed a little bit of help and help is just a click away.
But if you are a pro, you can dive deeper into all kinds of different courses.
If you want to master science problems every day,
go to brilliant.org/braincraft
and sign up for free.
And also the first 200 BrainCraft viewers that go to that link
Will get 20% off the annual premium subscription.
So, when we basically finished this video.
I realized that I forgot to complete the story of my transformation or whatever,
and basically revisit the people who were calling me type A.

Well now that you know “Type A personality”
is a myth, instead of calling people like me Type A
You could say that I pay attention to every detail.
That I never settle for mediocrity.
I overachieve expectations.

Just like this Type A deodorant that my editor Dominique
found in Target.

If you can support us to create more videos,
the link to the BrainCraft Patreon is in the
doobly do.

Thanks for watching and never settle for
mediocrity.
